content: How can I help you today?

I'm not exactly sure where to start. My wife thought it would be good for me to talk to someone, but honestly, I'm skeptical about whether this will help. Things have just been overwhelming at home, and I don’t see a way out of all this stress.

It's okay to feel unsure about where to start, and it’s understandable to feel skeptical—that’s perfectly normal. It sounds like life has been really overwhelming lately, and carrying all that stress can feel like a heavy weight. What’s been feeling the most difficult for you recently?

I think it's everything piling up all at once. My son has been having behavioral issues, and my wife and I can't agree on how to help him. It's affecting our marriage, and honestly, I feel like we're falling apart. On top of that, I can’t focus at work or enjoy anything anymore.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot on your shoulders—worrying about your son, the strain it’s putting on your marriage, and feeling disconnected from work and the things you used to enjoy. That must feel exhausting and maybe even isolating at times. What do you feel weighs on you the most right now?

My son’s struggles definitely weigh on me the most. It’s like I don’t know how to help him, and it breaks my heart. But then not being able to figure it out with my wife adds this extra layer of stress, and it feels like we’re both drifting further apart. Everything just feels so out of control.

It sounds incredibly painful to feel like you’re trying so hard to help your son but still feel at a loss, especially when it’s bringing tension into your marriage. That sense of everything feeling out of control can be overwhelming and leave you feeling stuck. What helps you get through moments like this, even in small ways?

Honestly, I don’t even know anymore. I used to feel like I could handle stress better, but now it feels like nothing really works. Sometimes I just try to shut it all out, but that doesn’t really help in the long run. I guess I’ve been running on empty.

It must be exhausting to feel like you're running on empty and that your usual ways of coping aren’t helping the way they used to. Shutting things out may feel like the only option in the moment, but it sounds like you're longing for something that can truly help you move forward. What do you think might give you even a small sense of control or relief right now?

Maybe taking a step back and focusing on one thing at a time could help. But honestly, I don’t even know where to start. Everything feels so overwhelming that it’s hard to pinpoint what would make a difference.

Focusing on one thing at a time sounds like a thoughtful way to start easing the overwhelm—it shows you’re looking for ways to regain some control. Deciding where to begin when everything is tangled can feel tough, though. If you could take a step back, what’s one area—whether it’s with your son, your marriage, or even just carving out a moment for yourself—that you feel might help you take a small first step forward?

I guess it would be with my son. If I could figure out how to help him or at least feel like I’m making some progress, maybe things wouldn’t feel so heavy at home. But it’s hard because I’m not even sure what the right thing to do for him is.

Focusing on your son makes sense, especially since his well-being seems to be so important to you. It’s clear you really care about making sure he’s okay, even though not knowing how best to help him feels overwhelming right now. What’s one thing you’ve tried so far, or something that’s worked, even a little, in supporting him?

We’ve tried talking to him and setting clear rules, but nothing seems to stick. It’s like he’s acting out and we can’t get to the root of what’s really bothering him. I feel like I’m failing as a parent, which makes it even harder to figure out what to do next.

It sounds like you’ve been doing your best, trying to communicate and set guidelines for your son, even when it feels like nothing is working. Feeling like you're failing as a parent must be a heavy burden, especially when your heart is so invested in helping him. What do you think is behind his behavior, or what’s been on his mind, based on what you’ve observed?

It’s hard to say for sure, but I feel like he might be struggling with something emotionally or socially. Maybe school issues or feeling misunderstood. I just don’t know how to get him to open up, and it’s frustrating to not have answers.

It sounds like you're really trying to tune into what he might be feeling, even though it’s frustrating not to have clear answers about what’s going on. It shows how much you care and want to support him. What kind of moments have you noticed when he seems more open or willing to share, even just a little?

Sometimes he opens up a bit when we’re doing something together, like playing a game or driving somewhere. But even then, it’s like he only gives me little pieces, and I’m left trying to figure out the rest. It’s tough because I want him to feel safe talking to me, but I don’t know if I’m doing enough.

It’s understandable to question if you’re doing enough when all you want is to be there for your son. Those moments during activities together, when he shares even a little, seem like steps in the right direction. It takes patience and effort to create that safe space for him, and it sounds like you’re making it a priority. What would it feel like to focus on building more of those shared moments, without pressuring yourself for all the answers right away?

It might help, I guess. Focusing on spending time with him without trying to fix things right away could take some of the pressure off both of us. Maybe if we just connect more through those moments, he’ll feel safer opening up in his own time. It’s worth a try.

That sounds like a thoughtful way forward—shifting your focus to connecting with your son through those moments without the immediate pressure of solving everything all at once. It seems like you’re recognizing the value in creating that safe and steady foundation for him. Is there a particular activity you think you might start with to spend some more of that time together?
